I'm afraid that this could get us into trouble.
What this does is basically set a private field on the CDI proxy. For mock that works great because the mock is just some object. But in this case you would be setting the that private field to the CDI proxy itself.
I really think we need to find a more safe way of providing this facility.
timeline.author: geoand

replies.bodyText:
I am not sure I am following the concern.
In both the mock and spy use cases we are wrapping an Object into the Mockito Framework.
In the case of a Mock that is that Object is instantiated with null for all internal variables, and the Mockito Framework is set to doReturn(null) for any method that returns anything, or doNothing() for methods that return void.
In the case of the Spy that Object is a fully instantiated Object with all of the variables set how they are expected. Then the Mockito Framework will by default call doCallRealMethod() on all method calls into that Object.
In both cases, we are putting into the CDI proxy a Mockito wrapped Object.
replies.author: aaron-rogers82

replies.bodyText: The problem is that with the Spy, what you are putting in, actually contains a reference to the object itself, no?
replies.author: geoand

replies.bodyText:
Yes, you are just using a wrapper pattern to provide additional functionality to the Object.
At the end, the CDI proxy isn't pointing to the first Object it originally created, it is pointing to the Mockito Framework wrapped Object. If the CDI interacts with that Bean, it will be doing so to the wrapped Object, not to the original Bean itself.

replies.bodyText:
I think that it shoudln't be a problem although it's a bit "tangled".
There is a difference though because for @InjectMock a mock object is created and injected into the test class instance AND this mock is set to the mock field of the relevant client proxy object so that any client proxy method invocation is redirected to the mock.
For @InjectSpy a copy (according to the javadoc) of the client proxy object is created AND then this copy is set to the mock field of the relevant client proxy object. And it seems to work because the spy copy is created before the mock field is set and so if the client proxy is invoked (i.e. from another bean) the spy copy that has mock=null is used and so non-stubbed methods delegate to the underlying bean instance.

replies.bodyText: I'm not sure it's a good idea because if Mockito.spy() copies the state and does not delegate to the original instance we may end up with unexpected behavior. Let's say we have @ApplicationScoped Foo then @InjectSpy Foo -> this creates a copy of Foo instance. Now if you call an unstubbed method on the spy instance the state of the original bean instance does not change. Ideally, test methods should not be connected in any way but since the @ApplicationScoped beans are shared...

replies.bodyText:
I provided a few reasons in the documentation.
An example, in my current project I am working on, we have three possible methods that will all return the same object, but will go about looking up the data for the object different ways. We determine which method to call based on the JSON object passed into the project. When testing, we don't really want to alter how the code operates, we just want to be able to verify that the logic called the correct method.
To do that with a Mock it would have to create the mock and then in setup (@beforeeach) call doCallRealMethod().when(logic).method() for each public/protected/package private method on the class. Just creating a Spy eliminates that setup and simplifies maintenance as new methods are added.
For the majority of time, a Mock is just fine and will accomplish the majority of testing. Having the ability to use a Spy just provides more options to use when they are beneficial.
